Topic tmoney

  • B41505AF-AC7A-4238-AB31-AC2803A3A26B

    • tmoney
    • tpercentage

    Mr and Mrs Newland and their $2$ children were going to a pop concert.

    The prices were as follows

    Cost
    Adult$\pounds 45.00$
    Child$\pounds 30.50$

    %empty%

    %empty%

      • What is the total cost for all four of the family to go to the concert?

        $ \begin{aligned} \text{Total cost} &= 2 \times \text{Adult} + 2 \times \text{Child} \\ &= 2 \times 45 + 2 \times 30.5 \\ &= 90 + 61 \\ &= \pounds 151 \end{aligned} $

        $\pounds 151$

        • To see the mid-week show there is a special offer where a family ticket, for $2$ adults and $2$ children, costs only $\pounds 125$.

          How much would this ticket save the family?

          $ \begin{aligned} \text{Saving} &= \text{Full price} - \text{Special Offer} \\ &= 151 - 125 \\ &= \pounds 26 \end{aligned} $

          $\pounds 26$

          • $17600$ people attended the concert.

            Given that $40 \%$ of these were adults, how many people were adults?

            $ \begin{aligned} \text{Adults} &= 40 \% \ \text{of} \ 17600 \\ &= \dfrac {40} {100} \times 17600 \\ &= \dfrac {40 \times 17600} {100} \\ &= \dfrac {40 \times 176 \times 100} {100} \\ &= \dfrac {40 \times 176 \times 1\cancel{0}\cancel{0}} {1\cancel{0}\cancel{0}} \\ &= {40 \times 176} \\ &= 7040 \end{aligned} $

            $7040$

          aldenham-school--11-plus--maths--2019--sample-paper-1.toml

          rag_up_oldpr

        • 05561C2E-68D5-42DC-876C-EC372F879900

          • tprofit
          • tmoney

          The original price of a bicycle is $\pounds 260$. Which of these is the better deal?

          Show workings.

          Original price $= \pounds 260$

          Let's look at Deal A.

          If the price is reduced by $25 \%$, then the sale price will be $100 - 25 = 75 \%$ of the original price. Using that, we get

          $ \begin{aligned} \text{Deal A} &= 75 \% \ \text{of} \ 260 \\ &= \dfrac {75} {100} \times 260 \\ &= \dfrac {75 \times 260 } {100} \\ &= \dfrac {25 \times 3 \times 4 \times 65 } {25 \times 4} \\ &= \dfrac {\cancel{25} \times 3 \times \cancel{4} \times 65 } {\cancel{25} \times \cancel{4}} \\ &= 3 \times 65 \\ &= \pounds 195 \end{aligned} $

          Deal B $= \pounds 205$

          From the above calcuation, we can see that Deal A is better than Deal B.

          Deal A

          aldenham-school--11-plus--maths--2019--sample-paper-1.toml

          rag_up_oldpr

        • 46202F60-6AFF-44CC-9683-1646AF85C31F

          • tmoney

          Mrs Prince wishes to buy each member of her class a photo frame as a present. There are $24$ pupils in her class and each photo frame costs $\pounds 3.75$.

          Find the total cost of all $24$ frames.

          As per the question,

          $ \begin{aligned} \text{Count of pupils} &= 24 \\ \text{Cost per frame} &= \pounds 3.75 \\ \text{Total cost} &= 24 \times 3.75 \\ &= \pounds 90 \end{aligned} $

          $\pounds 90$

          aldenham-school--11-plus--maths--2019--sample-paper-1.toml

          rag_up_oldpr

        • D48EBB7F-6353-41D8-8F7E-D81284AECC1E

          • tpercentage
          • tmoney
          • tinequality

          Which sign makes each of the following statements true?

          $\large { \boxed{\phantom{5} > \phantom{5} } \quad \boxed{\phantom{5} < \phantom{5} } \quad \boxed{\phantom{5} = \phantom{5} } }$

          %empty%

          %empty%

            • $0.022 \quad \ldots \quad 0.2$

              $0.022 \quad \boxed{\green{<}} \quad 0.2$

              $0.022 < 0.2$

              • $15\%$ of $\pounds 300\ \quad \ldots \quad 20\%$ of $\pounds 240$

                Let's calculate the first value.

                $ \begin{aligned} &= 15\% \text{ of } \pounds 300 \\ &= \dfrac{15}{100} \times 300 \\ &= \dfrac{15 \times 300}{100} \\ &= \dfrac{15 \times 3\cancel{0}\cancel{0}}{1\cancel{0}\cancel{0}} \\ &= 15 \times 3 \\ &= \pounds 45 \end{aligned} $

                Let's calculate the second value.

                $ \begin{aligned} &= 20\% \text{ of } \pounds 240 \\ &= \dfrac{20}{100} \times 240 \\ &= \dfrac{20 \times 240}{100} \\ &= \dfrac{2\cancel{0} \times 24\cancel{0}}{1\cancel{0}\cancel{0}} \\ &= 2 \times 24 \\ &= \pounds 48 \end{aligned} $

                Using the calculation above,

                $15\%$ of $\pounds 300\ \quad \boxed{\green{<}} \quad 20\%$ of $\pounds 240$

                $15\%$ of $\pounds 300\ \quad < \quad 20\%$ of $\pounds 240$

                • $\dfrac {2}{5}$ of $\pounds 40\ \quad \ldots \quad 25\%$ of $\pounds 64$

                  Let's calculate the first value.

                  $ \begin{aligned} &= \dfrac {2}{5} \text{ of } \pounds 40 \\ &= \dfrac{2 \times 40}{5} \\ &= \dfrac{2 \times 5 \times 8}{5} \\ &= \dfrac{2 \times \cancel{5} \times 8}{\cancel{5}} \\ &= 2 \times 8 \\ &= \pounds 16 \end{aligned} $

                  Let's calculate the second value.

                  $ \begin{aligned} &= 25\% \text{ of } \pounds 64 \\ &= \dfrac{25}{100} \times 64 \\ &= \dfrac{25 \times 64}{100} \\ &= \dfrac{1600}{100} \\ &= \dfrac{16\cancel{0}\cancel{0}}{1\cancel{0}\cancel{0}} \\ &= \pounds 16 \end{aligned} $

                  Using the calculation above,

                  $\dfrac {2}{5}$ of $\pounds 40\ \quad \boxed{\green{=}} \quad 25\%$ of $\pounds 64$

                  $\dfrac {2}{5}$ of $\pounds 40\ \quad = \quad 25\%$ of $\pounds 64$

                aldenham-school--11-plus--maths--2019--sample-paper-1.toml

                rag_up_oldpr

              • D8CD5DBE-7A2A-47CB-9D63-90512FB0BB7B

                • ttime
                • tmoney

                Mrs Green parked her car in a car park at $9.00 \ \text{am}$. She drove out of the car park at $5.00 \ \text{pm}$.

                Car Parking Charges: $\pounds 1.80$ per hour

                %empty%

                %empty%

                  • For how many hours was her car in the car park?

                    As per the question,

                    $ \begin{aligned} \text{Hours in the car park} &= 5.00 \ \text{pm} - 9.00 \ \text{am} \\ &= 8 \ \text{hours} \end{aligned} $

                    $8 \ \text{hours}$

                    • How much did she pay, in total, for parking her car?

                      $ \begin{aligned} \text{Total parking charges} &= 1.80 \times 8 \\ &= \pounds 14.40 \end{aligned} $

                      $\pounds 14.40$

                    aldenham-school--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-2.toml

                    rag_up_oldpr

                  • 56B40B8C-468B-4A69-83E1-B687C31C142F

                    • tmoney

                    %empty%

                    %empty%

                      • The entry prices at a theme park are

                        Price
                        Adults$\pounds 6.25$ each
                        Children$\pounds 2.50$ each

                        Find the cost for $2$ adults and $4$ children to visit the theme park.

                        $ \begin{aligned} \text{Total cost} &= 2 \times \text{Adult} + 4 \times \text{Child} \\ &= 2 \times 6.25 + 4 \times 2.50 \\ &= 12.5 + 10 \\ &= \pounds 22.50 \end{aligned} $

                        $\pounds 22.50$

                        • The entry prices for a group are

                          Price
                          Adults$\pounds 5.00$ each
                          Children$\pounds 3.00$ each

                          A group of adults and children goes to the theme park for a cost of $\pounds 44$.

                          There are $4$ adults in the group. How many children are in the group?

                          Let the number of children $= c$

                          As per the question,

                          $ \begin{aligned} 4 \times 5 + c \times 3 &= 44 \\ 20 + 3c &= 44 \\ 3c &= 44 - 20 \\ 3c &= 24 \\ c &= \dfrac{24}{3} \\ c &= 8 \end{aligned} $

                          Number of children $= 8$

                          $8$

                        aldenham-school--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-2.toml

                        rag_up_oldpr

                      • 1622DD6F-538D-47B0-8E04-EE946A7719E6

                        • talgebra
                        • tmoney

                        If $2$ apples and $1$ banana cost $\pounds 1.20$

                        and

                        $1$ apple and $2$ bananas cost $\pounds 1.35$, find the cost of an apple and a banana separately.

                        Let the cost of an apple (in $\text{pence}$) $= a$

                        Let the cost of a banana (in $\text{pence}$) $= b$

                        It is really important to use the right units in calculations and convert where required. Let's convert all the costs into $\text{pence}$.

                        As per the question,

                        $ \begin{aligned} 2a + b &= 120 \\ a + 2b &= 135 \end{aligned} $

                        We have got $2$ variables and we have $2$ equations to solve them. Let's eliminate to reduce it to just one variable.

                        Multiply the second equation by $2$.

                        $ \begin{aligned} 2 \times a + 2 \times 2b &= 2 \times 135 \\ 2a + 4b &= 270 \end{aligned} $

                        Subtract the first equation from the second to reduce it to one variable.

                        $ \begin{aligned} 2a + 4b - (2a + b) &= 270 - 120 \\ 2a + 4b -2a -b &= 150 \\ 3b &= 150 \\ b &= \dfrac {150} {3} \\ b &= 50 \ \text{pence} \end{aligned} $

                        Cost of a banana $= 50 \ \text{pence}$.

                        Let's substitute the value of $b$ in one of the initial equations to find the cost of an apple.

                        $ \begin{aligned} 2a + b &= 120 \\ 2a + 50 &= 120 \\ 2a &= 120 - 50 \\ 2a &= 70 \\ a &= \dfrac {70} {2} \\ a &= 35 \ \text{pence} \end{aligned} $

                        Apple $= 35 \ \text{pence}$

                        Banana $= 50 \ \text{pence}$

                        aldenham-school--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-2.toml

                        rag_up_oldpr

                      • 36F489C8-4D43-443D-8436-ED8F6DD25EB8

                        • talgebra
                        • tmoney

                        Sophie and her friends decided to raise money for charity by baking and selling cookies. They set themselves a target of $\pounds 200$ profit to raise.

                        Each cookie cost them $10 \text{p}$ to make and they sold them for $50 \text{p}$.

                        How many cookies did they need to sell to reach their target?

                        It is really important to use the right units in calculations and convert where required.

                        Let's convert the total amount into pence.

                        $ \begin{aligned} \text{Total amount} &= \pounds 200 \\ &= 200 \times 100 \text{p} \\ &= 20000 \text{p} \end{aligned} $

                        $ \begin{aligned} \text{Cost of each cookie} &= 10 \text{p} \\ \text{Sale Price for each cookie} &= 50 \text{p} \\ \text{Profit per cookie} &= 50 - 10 \\ &= 40 \text{p} \end {aligned} $

                        $ \begin{aligned} \text{Number of cookies needed} &= \dfrac {\text{Total target}} {\text{Profit per cookie}} \\ &= \dfrac {20000} {40} \\ &= 500 \end {aligned} $

                        This can be solved using algebra as well.

                        Let the number of cookies $= c$

                        As per the question,

                        $ \begin{aligned} (50 - 10) \times c &= 20000 \\ 40c &= 20000 \\ c &= \dfrac {20000} {40} \\ c &= 500 \end {aligned} $

                        Number of cookies needed $= 500$

                        $500$

                        aldenham-school--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-3.toml

                        rag_up_oldpr

                      • B9A0C103-F37E-45E0-8E72-914E65E4982D

                        • tprofit
                        • tmoney

                        $200$ items are bought for $\pounds 2.10$. Each are now worth $\pounds 1.61$. Find the total loss.

                        $ \begin{aligned} \text{Loss for } 1 \text{ item} &= 2.10 - 1.61 \\ &= 0.49 \\ \text{Loss for } 200 \text{ items} &= 0.49 \times 200 \\ &= \pounds 98 \end{aligned} $

                        $\pounds 98$

                        aldenham-school--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-3.toml

                        rag_up_oldpr

                      • 8B53538F-9FA0-4E30-B73C-B54B18223907

                        • tmoney

                        Katie‚Äôs mum gives her $\pounds 10$.

                        She spends $\pounds 1.90$ on magazines, $\pounds 2.45$ on a birthday card and $75 \text{p}$ on chocolate. How much money does she have left?

                        It is really important to use the right units in calculations and convert where required.

                        Let's convert all the expenses into $\text{pence}$.

                        $ \begin{aligned} \text{Money spent} &= \pounds 1.90 + \pounds 2.45 + 75 \text{p} \\ &= 190 \text{p} + 245 \text{p} + 75 \text{p} \\ &= 510 \text{p} \\ \text{Money left} &= \pounds 10 - 510 \text{p} \\ &= 1000 \text{p} - 510 \text{p} \\ &= 490 \text{p} \\ &= \pounds 4.90 \end{aligned} $

                        $\pounds 4.90$

                        aldenham-school--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-4.toml

                        rag_up_oldpr

                      • D24B2AA0-CEC4-4120-B456-6DFE977605BF

                        • tmoney
                        • tratio
                        • talgebra

                        How much will $46$ lollipops cost if they cost $\pounds 1.25$ each?

                        This can be solved using ratios.

                        $ \begin{aligned} 1 \text{ lollipop} &: \pounds 1.25 \\ 1 \times 46 \text{ lollipops} &: \pounds 1.25 \times 46 \\ 46 \text{ lollipops} &: \pounds 57.50 \end{aligned} $

                        $\pounds 57.50$

                        aldenham-school--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-4.toml

                        rag_up_oldpr

                      • CCEC5B5B-5806-4EE1-84D1-019B559F2867

                        • tpercentage
                        • tmoney

                        Which of these amounts is the cheaper? Circle your answer.

                        $25 \%$ of $\pounds 64$ or $20 \%$ of $\pounds 75$

                        Show your working.

                        Let's calculate both the values.

                        $ \begin{aligned} \text{First amount} &= 25 \% \text{ of } \pounds 64 \\ &= \dfrac{25}{100} \times 64 \\ &= \dfrac{25 \times 64}{100} \\ &= \dfrac{25 \times 4 \times 16}{25 \times 4} \\ &= \dfrac{\cancel{25} \times \cancel{4} \times 16}{\cancel{25} \times \cancel{4}} \\ &= \pounds 16 \\
                        \text{Second amount} &= 20 \% \text{ of } \pounds 75 \\ &= \dfrac{20}{100} \times 75 \\ &= \dfrac{20 \times 75}{100} \\ &= \dfrac{20 \times 5 \times 15}{20 \times 5} \\ &= \dfrac{\cancel{20} \times \cancel{5} \times 15}{\cancel{20} \times \cancel{5}} \\ &= \pounds 15
                        \end{aligned} $

                        From the calculation above, $20 \%$ of $\pounds 75$ is cheaper.

                        $20 \%$ of $\pounds 75$

                        aldenham-school--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-4.toml

                        rag_up_oldpr

                      • 3535C8D5-DE86-4450-A6FD-9386A9F13C8D

                        • tmoney
                        • tprofit
                        • tpercentage

                        Have a look at the deals ticket vendors are offering:

                        Each ticket cost $\pounds 480$.

                        Super Tickets
                        Buy $2$ get $1$ free
                        Tickets R US
                        Buy $3$ get $25 \%$ off total price
                        Ticket Galore
                        Buy $1$ get $2$ at $40 \%$ off
                        Top Ticket
                        Buy $2$ get $1$ half price

                        If I needed $3$ tickets, put the vendors in order (cheapest first).

                        Let's calculate the best price of $3$ tickets from each vendor.

                        Super Tickets

                        $ \begin{aligned} \text{Cost of } 3 \text{ tickets} &= 480 \times 2 \\ &= \pounds 960 \end{aligned} $

                        Tickets R US

                        If the total price is reduced by $25 \%$, then the sale price will be $100 - 25 = 75 \%$ of the original price. Using that, we get

                        $ \begin{aligned} \text{Cost of } 3 \text{ tickets} &= 75\% \times 480 \times 3 \\ &= \dfrac{75}{100} \times 480 \times 3 \\ &= \dfrac{75 \times 480 \times 3}{100} \\ &= \dfrac{25 \times 3 \times 4 \times 120 \times 3}{25 \times 4} \\ &= \dfrac{\cancel{25} \times 3 \times \cancel{4} \times 120 \times 3}{\cancel{25} \times \cancel{4}} \\ &= 3 \times 120 \times 3\\ &= \pounds 1080 \end{aligned} $

                        Ticket Galore

                        If the price is reduced by $40 \%$, then the sale price will be $100 - 40 = 60 \%$ of the original price. Using that, we get

                        $ \begin{aligned} \text{Cost of } 3 \text{ tickets} &= 480 + 60\% \times 480 \times 2 \\ &= 480 + \dfrac{60}{100} \times 480 \times 2 \\ &= 480 + \dfrac{60 \times 480 \times 2}{100} \\ &= 480 + \dfrac{6\cancel{0} \times 48\cancel{0} \times 2}{1\cancel{0}\cancel{0}} \\ &= 480 + 6 \times 48 \times 2 \\ &= 480 + 576 \\ &= \pounds 1056 \end{aligned} $

                        Top Ticket

                        If the price is reduced by $\dfrac{1}{2}$, then the sale price will be $1 - \dfrac{1}{2} = \dfrac{1}{2}$ of the original price. Using that, we get

                        $ \begin{aligned} \text{Cost of } 3 \text{ tickets} &= 480 \times 2 + \dfrac{1}{2} \times 480 \\ &= 960 + \dfrac{480}{2} \\ &= 960 + 240 \\ &= \pounds 1200 \end{aligned} $

                        Using the calculation above, the vendors in order (cheapest first):

                        VendorPrice
                        Super Tickets$\pounds 960$
                        Ticket Galore$\pounds 1056$
                        Tickets R US$\pounds 1080$
                        Top Ticket$\pounds 1200$

                        Super Tickets, Ticket Galore, Tickets R US, Top Ticket

                        aldenham-school--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-4.toml

                        rag_up_oldpr

                      • C37C7D80-A04A-4A0E-94DE-218ED2624A77

                        • tpercentage
                        • tmoney

                        Find $40\%$ of $\pounds 620$.

                        $ \begin{aligned} &= 40\% \text{ of } \pounds 620 \\ &= \dfrac{40}{100} \times 620 \\ &= \dfrac{4\cancel{0} \times 62\cancel{0}}{1\cancel{0}\cancel{0}} \\ &= 4 \times 62 \\ &= \pounds 248 \end{aligned} $

                        $\pounds 248$

                        alderley-edge-school-for-girls--11-plus--maths--2019--sample-paper-1.toml

                        Find $20 \%$ of $\pounds 80$

                        $ \begin{aligned} &= 20\% \text{ of } \pounds 80 \\ &= \dfrac{20}{100} \times 80 \\ &= \dfrac{20 \times 80}{100} \\ &= \dfrac{2\cancel{0} \times 8\cancel{0}}{1\cancel{0}\cancel{0}} \\ &= 2\times 8\\ &= \pounds 16 \end{aligned} $

                        $\pounds 16$

                        $ \begin{aligned} &= \pounds 6 - \pounds 3.24 \\ &= \pounds 2.76 \end{aligned} $

                        • tmoney

                        Find $\dfrac{2}{5}$ of $\pounds 40$.

                        $ \begin{aligned} &= \dfrac {2}{5} \text{ of } \pounds 40 \\ &= \dfrac{2 \times 40}{5} \\ &= \dfrac{2 \times 5 \times 8}{5} \\ &= \dfrac{2 \times \cancel{5} \times 8}{\cancel{5}} \\ &= 2 \times 8 \\ &= \pounds 16 \end{aligned} $

                        $\pounds 16$

                          • 6D5C94CF-2D87-4416-AAA2-9227B6C1AC6A

                            • tmoney

                            I buy a pen and a pencil for $\pounds 1.10$. The pen costs $50 \text{p}$ more than the pencil. How much is the pen?

                            • $50 \text{p}$
                            • $60 \text{p}$
                            • $70 \text{p}$
                            • $80 \text{p}$
                            • $90 \text{p}$

                            It is really important to use the right units in calculations and convert where required.

                            Let's convert the total amount into pence.

                            $ \begin{aligned} \text{Total cost} &= \pounds 1.1 \\ &= 1.1 \times 100p \\ &= 110p \end{aligned} $

                            Let the price of pencil $= a$

                            As per the question

                            $ \begin{aligned} a + (50 + a) &= 110 \\ 2a + 50 &= 110 \\ 2a &= 110 - 50 \\ a &= \dfrac {60} {2} \\ a &= \dfrac {30 \times 2} {2} \\ a &= \dfrac {30 \times \cancel{2} } {\cancel {2} } \\ a &= 30\text{p} \end{aligned} $

                            So the cost of pen becomes

                            $ \begin{aligned} &= 50 + 30 &= 80\text{p} \end{aligned} $

                            $80 \text{p}$

                            TODOANSWER

                            alleyns-school--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-1.toml

                            rag_np_pr

                          • 3C332963-BE65-428D-ADC1-67AF0F572E10

                            • tmoney

                            I buy $6$ packets of crisps from the $\pounds 1.99$ store where everything costs $\pounds 1.99$. How much change do I get from $\pounds 20$?

                            • $6 \text{p}$
                            • $\pounds 6.99$
                            • $\pounds 11.94$
                            • $\pounds 4.06$
                            • $\pounds 8.06$

                            TODOWORKING

                            TODOWORKING

                            TODOANSWER

                            TODOANSWER

                            alleyns-school--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-2.toml

                            rag_up_notstarted

                          • A9BB615E-D457-47F6-AF4E-CD7BA00D2171

                            • tnumber
                            • tmoney

                            %empty%

                            %empty%

                            %empty%

                              • Angus and his six friends have collected $756$ football stickers, which they all share out equally.
                                How many stickers do they each get?

                                As per the question,

                                $ \begin{aligned} \text{Stickers each will get} &= \dfrac {756} {7} \\ &= \dfrac {7 \times 108} {7} \\ &= \dfrac {\cancel{7} \times 108} {\cancel{7}} \\ &= 108 \end{aligned} $

                                $108

                                • Today is Emma's $29 \text{th}$ birthday. How many months old is she?

                                  As per the question,

                                  $ \begin{aligned} \text{Months Emma is old} &= 29 \times 12 \\ &= 348 \end{aligned} $

                                  $348$

                                  • Amar works for $45$ weeks each year. His total cost of travelling to and from work is $\pounds 630$ each year. How much is that per week?

                                    As per the question,

                                    $ \begin{aligned} \text{Amar's travelling cost per week} &= \dfrac {\pounds 630} {45} \\ &= \dfrac {14 \times 45} {45} \\ &= \dfrac {14 \times \cancel{45}} {\cancel{45}} \\ &= \pounds 14 \end{aligned} $

                                    $\pounds 14$

                                  bancrofts-school--11-plus--maths--2013--sample-paper-1.toml

                                  rag_sc_pr

                                                %empty%

                                                %empty%

                                                %empty%

                                                  • A crate holds $8$ cartons of milk. How many crates are needed to hold $349$ cartons?

                                                    As per the question,

                                                    $ \begin{aligned} \text{Crates needed to hold 349 cartons} &= \dfrac {349} {8} \\ &= 43 \dfrac {5} {8} \\ &= 44 \end{aligned}

                                                    Total crates needed to hold $349$ cartons $= 44$ $

                                                    $44$

                                                    • Seven adult cinema tickets cost $\pounds 24.50$. How much will four adult tickets cost?

                                                      As per the question,

                                                      $ \begin{aligned} \text{Cost of 4 adult tickets} &= \pounds 24.50 \times 4 \\ &= \pounds 98 \end{aligned} $

                                                      $\pounds 98$

                                                      • Flora is exactly eleven and a half years old. How many months old is she?

                                                        As per the question,

                                                        $ \begin{aligned} \text{Months flora is old} &= 11 \dfrac {1} {2} \times 12 \\ &= \dfrac {23 \times 12} {2} \\ &= \dfrac {23 \times 2 \times 6} {2} \\ &= \dfrac {23 \times \cancel{2} \times 6} {\cancel{2}} \\ &= 23 \times 6 \\ &= 138 \end{aligned} $

                                                        $138$

                                                      bancrofts-school--11-plus--maths--2016--sample-paper-2.toml

                                                      rag_sc_pr

                                                        • 61824054-48C2-4222-94CE-B049FCF364CB

                                                          • talgebra
                                                          • tmoney

                                                          %empty%

                                                          %empty%

                                                          %empty%

                                                            • The tables in the Dining Hall can each seat $8$ pupils.

                                                              How many tables are needed to seat $180$ pupils?

                                                              As per the question,

                                                              $ \begin{aligned} \text{Tables needed to seat 180 pupils} &= \dfrac {180} {8} \\ &= 22 \dfrac {4} {8} \\ &= 23 \end{aligned} $

                                                              Total tables needed to seat $180$ pupil $= 23$

                                                              $23$

                                                              • Jake paid a $\pounds 50$ deposit for a bike, then monthly payments of $\pounds 25$ each. The bike cost $\pounds 275$.

                                                                How many monthly payments did Jake have to make to buy it?

                                                                As per the question,

                                                                $ \begin{aligned} \text{Cost of 4 adult tickets} &= \dfrac {\pounds 275 - \pounds 50} {25} \\ &= \dfrac {225} {25} \\ &= \dfrac {9 \times 25} {25} \\ &= \dfrac {9 \times \cancel{25}} {\cancel{25}} \\ &= \pounds 9 \end{aligned} $

                                                                $\pounds 9$

                                                                • There are $500$ pupils at Lily's school.

                                                                  There are $30$ more girls than boys.

                                                                  How many girls are there?

                                                                  Let the number of girls $= g$

                                                                  As per the question,

                                                                  $ \begin{aligned} \text{Number of girls} &= \text{Total pupils} - \text{Number of boys} \\ g &= 500 - (g - 30) \\ g &= 500 - g + 30 \\ g + g &= 500 + 30 \\ 2g &= 530 \\ g &= \dfrac {530} {2} g &= \dfrac {2 \times 265} {2} \\ g &= \dfrac {\cancel{2} \times 265} {\cancel{2}} \\ g &= 265 \end{aligned} $

                                                                  Number of girls at Lily's school $= 265$

                                                                  $265$

                                                                bancrofts-school--11-plus--maths--2017--sample-paper-3.toml

                                                                                                          Asif wants to buy a computer game that costs $\pounds 32.99$ in the shop but decides to wait until there is a sale. In the sale Asif buys the computer game for $\pounds 25.62$. How much money did he save?

                                                                                                          $ \begin {aligned} &= 32.99 - 25.62 \\ &= \pounds 7.37 \end {aligned} $

                                                                                                          $\pounds 7.37$

                                                                                                          colfes-school--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper.toml

                                                                                                          rag_nc_red

                                                                                                        • D71A8D20-2E8A-4417-920F-57E32AF54FC8

                                                                                                          • tmoney

                                                                                                          The cost in pounds, $C$, of going to the cinema can be worked out using the formula

                                                                                                          $C = 8a + 3k$

                                                                                                          In this formula $a$ stands for the number of adults and $k$ stands for the number of children.

                                                                                                              A new mobile phone app is sold for $79$ pence per download and proves to be very popular so that $150$ people are downloading the app every day. The person who created the app gets $44$ pence every time it is downloaded and she gets paid at the end of each week.

                                                                                                              How many weeks will it take for her to have $\pounds 2,000$?

                                                                                                            • 0A52D945-A28D-4AF7-B094-8C90084E6EB6

                                                                                                              • tmoney

                                                                                                              Refer to the following school canteen price list for this question:

                                                                                                              Pasta Salad $\ldots 95 \text{p}$

                                                                                                              Baguette $\ldots 85 \text{p}$

                                                                                                              Apple $\ldots 40 \text{p}$

                                                                                                              Fruit Crumble $\ldots \pounds 1.15$

                                                                                                              Curry and Rice $\ldots \pounds 2.30$

                                                                                                              Mr. Sanders wants to buy a class set of $25$ packed lunches - each with a pasta salad, a baguette and an apple.

                                                                                                              How much will he have to pay in total?

                                                                                                              $ \begin {aligned} \text {Total cost} &= 25 \times (95 + 85 + 40) \\ &= 25 \times 220 \ \text{p} \\ &= 25 \times \pounds \dfrac {220} {100} \\ &= 25 \times 2.2 \\ &= \pounds 55 \end {aligned} $

                                                                                                              $\pounds 55$

                                                                                                              csse--11-plus--maths--2015--sample-paper-1.toml

                                                                                                              rag_nj_pr

                                                                                                            • 4E57F639-F608-4331-AA87-22415889E213

                                                                                                              • tmoney

                                                                                                              TJ is sorting out prices for the snack shop at school, he has a box of $15$ chocolate bars. He bought the while box for $\pounds 4.05$. He plans to sell the bars for $35 \text{p}$ each.

                                                                                                              %empty%

                                                                                                              %empty%

                                                                                                                • How much money will TJ recieve if he sells all 15 bars at 35 \text{p}$?

                                                                                                                  $ \begin{aligned} \text {TJ will recieve} &= 15 \times 35 \ \text {p} - \pounds 4.05 \\ &= 15 \times \pounds \dfrac {35} {100} - \pounds 4.05 \\ &= 15 \times 0.35 - 4.05 \\ &= 5.25 - 4.05 \\ &= \pounds 1.2 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                  $\pounds 1.2$

                                                                                                                  • How much did TJ pay each bar when he bought the box?

                                                                                                                    $ \begin{aligned} \text {TJ paid} &= 4.05 \div 15 \\ &= \dfrac {4.05} {15} \\ &= \pounds 0.27 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                    $\pounds 0.27$

                                                                                                                    • TJ also has two types of cereal snacks: raisin bars and nut bars. Each raisin bar is $12 \text{p}$ more to buy than a nut bar. Nine raisin bars and twelve nut bars cost $\pounds 5.28$.

                                                                                                                      How much more do nine raisin bars cost than nine nut bars?

                                                                                                                                                • tfakeratio

                                                                                                                                                Robbie saves $\pounds 3.50$ every week. How much does he save in a year?

                                                                                                                                                As we know, there are $52$ weeks in a year. Using that,

                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} \text {Savings in a year} &= 52 \times 3.50 \\ &= \pounds 182 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                $\pounds 182$

                                                                                                                                                dame-alice-owens-school--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-1.toml

                                                                                                                                                • tmoney

                                                                                                                                                How much change would there be from a $\pounds 20$ note for Alice, Owen, Mum, Dad and Gran if they use the car park?

                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} \text{Total car parking charges} &= 1.50 \times 5 \\ &= \pounds 7.5 \\ \text{Change left } &= 20 - 7.5 \\ &= \pounds 12.5 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                $\pounds 12.5$

                                                                                                                                                The original cost of a mobile phone is $\pounds 76.30$. The price is reduced by $\pounds 18.45$.

                                                                                                                                                What is the new price?

                                                                                                                                              • 70533228-35C2-47ED-92E3-B482964231E0

                                                                                                                                                • talgebra
                                                                                                                                                • tmoney
                                                                                                                                                • tunit

                                                                                                                                                I buy $11$ chocolate bars costing $38 \text{p}$ each. How much change would I get from $\pounds 10$?

                                                                                                                                                It is really important to use the right units in calculations and convert where required. Let's convert all the costs into $\pounds$.

                                                                                                                                                As per the question,

                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} \text {Cost of chocolate Bars} &= 11 \times 38 \ \text{p} \\ &= 11 \times \pounds \dfrac {38} {100} \\ &= 11 \times \pounds 0.38 \\ &= \pounds 4.18 \\ \text {Change recieved} &= 10 - 4.18 \\ &= \pounds 5.82 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                $\pounds 5.82$

                                                                                                                                                devonport-high-school-for-boys--11-plus--maths--2016--sample-paper-1.toml

                                                                                                                                                rag_nj_g1

                                                                                                                                              • AEFC7170-49BA-433E-8F3B-1767FD16C053

                                                                                                                                                • tprofit
                                                                                                                                                • tmoney

                                                                                                                                                A car costing $\pounds 45000$ decreases in value by $15\%$ in one year.

                                                                                                                                                What is its new value?

                                                                                                                                                If the price is reduced by $15 \%$, then the new price will be $100 - 15 = 85 \%$ of the original price. Using that, we get

                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} \text{New value} &= 85 \% \ \text{of} \ 45000 \\ &= \dfrac {85} {100} \times 45000 \\ &= \dfrac {85 \times 45000} {100} \\ &= \dfrac {85 \times 450 \cancel {00} } {1 \cancel {00} } \\ &= 85 \times 450 \\ &= \pounds 38250 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                $\pounds 38250$

                                                                                                                                                devonport-high-school-for-boys--11-plus--maths--2016--sample-paper-1.toml

                                                                                                                                                rag_nj_g1

                                                                                                                                              • 368E6571-9487-45B7-AD17-93CB13083556

                                                                                                                                                • talgebra
                                                                                                                                                • tmoney

                                                                                                                                                For a train journey $t$ tickets cost $c = 8 + 12t$. How many tickets can I get for $\pounds 100$?

                                                                                                                                                As per the question,

                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} c &= 8 + 12 t \\ 100 &= 8 + 12 t \\ 12t &= 100 - 8 \\ 12t &= 92 \\ t &= \dfrac {92} {12} \\ t &= 7 \text{ remainder } 8 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                Max $7$ tickets can be bought with $\pounds 100$.

                                                                                                                                                $7$

                                                                                                                                                devonport-high-school-for-boys--11-plus--maths--2016--sample-paper-1.toml

                                                                                                                                                rag_nj_g1

                                                                                                                                              • 59660B71-3F8C-4A1A-A1EF-EA9884A61222

                                                                                                                                                • tratio
                                                                                                                                                • tmoney

                                                                                                                                                $48$ pencils cost $\pounds 11.04$. What is the cost of each pencil?

                                                                                                                                                Let's solve this using ratios.

                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} 48 \ \text{pencils} &: \pounds 11.04 \\ \dfrac {48} {48} \ \text{pencils} &: \pounds \dfrac {11.04} {48} \\ 1 \ \text{pencil} &: \pounds 0.23 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                $\pounds 0.23$

                                                                                                                                                devonport-high-school-for-boys--11-plus--maths--2016--sample-paper-1.toml

                                                                                                                                                I buy $11$ chocolate bars costing $27 \text{p}$ each. How much change would I get from $\pounds 5$?

                                                                                                                                                It is really important to use the right units in calculations and convert where required. Let's convert all the costs into $\pounds$.

                                                                                                                                                As per the question,

                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} \text {Cost of chocolate Bars} &= 11 \times 27 \ \text{p} \\ &= 11 \times \pounds \dfrac {27} {100} \\ &= 11 \times \pounds 0.27 \\ &= \pounds 2.97 \\ \text {Change recieved} &= 5 - 2.97 \\ &= \pounds 2.03 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                $\pounds 2.03$

                                                                                                                                                For a train journey $t$ tickets cost $c = 6 + 12t$. How many tickets can I get for $\pounds 100$?

                                                                                                                                                As per the question,

                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} c &= 6 + 12 t \\ 100 &= 6 + 12 t \\ 12t &= 100 - 6 \\ 12t &= 94 \\ t &= \dfrac {94} {12} \\ t &= 7 \text { remainder } 10 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                Max $7$ tickets can be bought with $\pounds 100$.

                                                                                                                                                $36$ pencils cost $\pounds 7.92$. What is the cost of each pencil?

                                                                                                                                                Let's solve this using ratios.

                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} 36 \ \text{pencils} &: \pounds 7.92 \\ \dfrac {36} {36} \ \text{pencils} &: \pounds \dfrac {7.92} {36} \\ 1 \ \text{pencil} &: \pounds 0.22 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                • tfraction
                                                                                                                                                • tmoney

                                                                                                                                                What is $\dfrac {3} {4}$ of $\pounds 4.48$?

                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} &= \dfrac {3} {4} \times 4.48 \\ &= \dfrac {3 \times 4.48} {4} \\ &= \dfrac {3 \times 1.12 \times 4} {4} \\ &= \dfrac {3 \times 1.12 \times \cancel {4}} {\cancel {4}} \\ &= 3 \times 1.12 \\ &= \pounds 3.36 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                $\pounds 3.36$

                                                                                                                                                The original cost of a television is $\pounds 176.10$ The price is reduced by $\pounds 14.75$.

                                                                                                                                                What is the new price?

                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} \text {New price} &= 176.10 - 14.75 \\ &= \pounds 161.35 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                $\pounds 161.35$

                                                                                                                                                For a train journey $t$ tickets cost $c = 6 + 10t$. How many tickets can I get for $\pounds 50$?

                                                                                                                                                As per the question,

                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} c &= 6 + 10 t \\ 50 &= 6 + 10 t \\ 10t &= 50 - 6 \\ 10t &= 44 \\ t &= \dfrac {44} {10} \\ t &= 4.4 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                $4$ tickets can be bought with $\pounds 50$.

                                                                                                                                                $4$

                                                                                                                                                devonport-high-school-for-boys--11-plus--maths--2019--sample-paper-4.toml

                                                                                                                                                rag_nj_pr

                                                                                                                                              • FA63BECC-AF6F-4CA6-91BD-2EF70EC554DA

                                                                                                                                                What percentage of $\pounds 5$ is $\pounds 1$?

                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} &= \dfrac {1} {5} \times 100 \\ &= \dfrac {100} {5} \\ &= \dfrac {20 \times 5} {5} \\ &= \dfrac {20 \times \cancel {5}} {\cancel{5}} \\ &= 20 \ \% \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                $20 \ \%$

                                                                                                                                                devonport-high-school-for-boys--11-plus--maths--2020--sample-paper-5.toml

                                                                                                                                                rag_nj_g1

                                                                                                                                              • 3CCF8DB4-38EC-47A3-B1E8-BAC6A3745EE8

                                                                                                                                                • tratio
                                                                                                                                                • tmoney

                                                                                                                                                Gym membership costs $\pounds 16$ a month. How much will it cost for a year?

                                                                                                                                                Let's solve this using ratios.

                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} 1 \ \text{month} &: \pounds 16 \\ 1 \times 12 \ \text{months} &: \pounds 16 \times 12 \\ 1 \ \text{year} &: \pounds 192 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                $\pounds 192$

                                                                                                                                                devonport-high-school-for-boys--11-plus--maths--2020--sample-paper-5.toml

                                                                                                                                                rag_nj_red

                                                                                                                                              • AE91E319-28CD-4E72-BACB-3D5D6A529FA0

                                                                                                                                                • tsubtraction
                                                                                                                                                • tmoney

                                                                                                                                                How much change would you get from $\pounds 10$ if you bought $7$ $\text{Chocco}^{\text{TM}}$ bars at $78 \text{p}$ each?

                                                                                                                                                It is really important to use the right units in calculations and convert where required. Let's convert all the costs into $\pounds$.

                                                                                                                                                As per the question,

                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} \text {Cost of Chocco bars} &= 7 \times 78 \ \text {p} \\ &= 7 \times \pounds \dfrac {78} {100} \\ &= 7 \times 0.78 \\ &= \pounds 5.46 \\ \text {Change recieved} &= 10 - 5.46 \\ &= \pounds 4.54 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                $\pounds 4.54$

                                                                                                                                                devonport-high-school-for-boys--11-plus--maths--2020--sample-paper-5.toml

                                                                                                                                                rag_nj_g1

                                                                                                                                              • 531E3BC7-C9D8-4A66-AD98-C9130D5EE75C

                                                                                                                                                • tmoney
                                                                                                                                                • tpercentage

                                                                                                                                                What is $15 \%$ of $\pounds 120$?

                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} &= 15 \% \ \text{of} \ \pounds 120 \\ &= \dfrac {15} {100} \times 120 \\ &= \dfrac {15 \times 120} {100} \\ &= \dfrac {5 \times 3 \times 6 \times 20} {5 \times 20} \\ &= \dfrac {\cancel {5} \times 3 \times 6 \times \cancel {20} } {\cancel {5} \times \cancel {20} } \\ &= 3 \times 6 \\ &= \pounds 18 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                $\pounds 18$

                                                                                                                                                devonport-high-school-for-boys--11-plus--maths--2020--sample-paper-5.toml

                                                                                                                                                rag_nj_g1

                                                                                                                                              • 1B8867E6-DD66-4F3F-811C-A4B71ADFBF90

                                                                                                                                                • tmoney
                                                                                                                                                • tprofit
                                                                                                                                                • tunitprompt

                                                                                                                                                A multipack of $12$ cans of Ned's cola cost $\pounds 6.95$.

                                                                                                                                                A single can of Ned's cola costs $65 \ \text{pence}$ if bought individually.

                                                                                                                                                Calculate how much cheaper it is to buy a multipack of $12$ cans than to buy $12$ cans individually, giving your answer in pence.

                                                                                                                                                As per the question,

                                                                                                                                                Cost of multipack of $12$ cans of Ned's cola $= \pounds 6.95$

                                                                                                                                                Cost of single can $=65 \text {pence}$

                                                                                                                                                Cost of $12$ cans if it bought individually $= 12 \times 65 \text {pence}$

                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} &= 12 \times 65 \\ &= 780 \text {pence} \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                Now convert the pounds into pence.

                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} \pounds 1 &= 100 \text {pence} \\ \pounds 6.95 &= 100 \times 6.95 \\ &= 695 \text {pence} \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} &= 780 - 695 \\ &= 85 \text {pence} \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                it is $85 \text{pence}$ cheaper to buy a multipack of $12$ cans than to buy $12$ cans individually.

                                                                                                                                                $85 \text {pence}$

                                                                                                                                                dulwich-college--11-plus--maths--9999--specimen-paper-a.toml

                                                                                                                                                rag_nm_pr

                                                                                                                                                • tmoney
                                                                                                                                                • tprofit

                                                                                                                                                A multipack of $15$ packets of crisps costs $\pounds 3.90$.

                                                                                                                                                A packet of crisps costs $35 \ \text{pence}$ if they are brought individually.

                                                                                                                                                Calculate how much cheaper it is to buy a multipack of $15$ packets of crisps than to buy $15$ packets individually.

                                                                                                                                                As per the question,

                                                                                                                                                Cost of multipack of $15$ packets of crisps $= \pounds 3.90$

                                                                                                                                                Cost of single packet of crisps $=35 \text {pence}$

                                                                                                                                                Cost of $15$ packets if it bought individually $= 15 \times 35 \text {pence}$

                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} &= 15 \times 35 \\ &= 525 \text {pence} \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                Now convert the pounds into pence.

                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} \pounds 1 &= 100 \text {pence} \\ \pounds 3.9 &= 100 \times 3.9 \\ &= 390 \text {pence} \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} &= 525 - 390 \\ &= 110 \text {pence} \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                it is $110 \text{pence}$ cheaper to buy a multipack of $15$ packets than to buy $12$ packets individually.

                                                                                                                                                $110 \text {pence}$

                                                                                                                                                • tmoney
                                                                                                                                                • tprofit
                                                                                                                                                • tunitprompt

                                                                                                                                                Clare went to the sweet shop with her weekly pocket money. She saw that lollipops cost $35 \text{p}$, and she worked out that if she bought $8$ lollipops she would end up with $30 \text{p}$ left from her pocket money.

                                                                                                                                                %empty%

                                                                                                                                                %empty%

                                                                                                                                                  • Work out how much money Clare had in total, giving your answer in pounds and pence.

                                                                                                                                                    As per the question,

                                                                                                                                                    No. of lollipops she bought $=8$

                                                                                                                                                    Cost of a lollipop $=35 \text {p}$

                                                                                                                                                    The money left after buying lollipops $=30 \text {p}$

                                                                                                                                                    Total money $= \text {Cost of a lollipop} \times \text {No. of lollipops she bought} + \text {the money left}$

                                                                                                                                                    $ \begin{aligned} &= 35 \times 8 + 30 \\ &= 310 \text {p} \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                    Now convert this into pounds and pence.

                                                                                                                                                    $ \begin{aligned} &= \dfrac {310} {100} \\ &= 3.1 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                    Total money $= \pounds 3 \ \text {and} \ 10 \text {p}$

                                                                                                                                                    $\pounds 3 \ \text {and} \ 10 \text {p}$

                                                                                                                                                    • She then worked out that if she bought only $5$ lollipops, she would have exactly the right amount of money left over to buy $3$ packets of jelly gums.

                                                                                                                                                      Work out the price of one packet of jelly gum.

                                                                                                                                                      As per the question,

                                                                                                                                                      Cost of $5$ lollipops $= 5 \times 35 \text {p}$

                                                                                                                                                      Cost of $3$ jelly gums $= 5 \times 35 \text {p}$

                                                                                                                                                      $ \begin{aligned} &= 5 \times 35 \\ &= 175 \text {p} \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                      Cost of $1$ jelly gum $= \dfrac {175} {3}$

                                                                                                                                                      $ \begin{aligned} &= \dfrac {175} {3} \\ &= 58.33 \text {p} \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                      $58.33 \text {p}$

                                                                                                                                                    dulwich-college--11-plus--maths--9999--specimen-paper-c.toml

                                                                                                                                                    rag_nm_pr

                                                                                                                                                  • B2A70184-F3DC-4A6A-AC4D-2F3D1B344BA6

                                                                                                                                                    • tpercentage
                                                                                                                                                    • tmoney

                                                                                                                                                    Jon has $30\%$ more money than Miguel and together they have $\pounds 46$. Calculate how much money Jon has.

                                                                                                                                                    Let Miguel has $x$ pounds.

                                                                                                                                                    As per the question,

                                                                                                                                                    Jon has $30 \%$ more money than Miguel.

                                                                                                                                                    Then,

                                                                                                                                                    Jon has $x + 30 \% \ \text {of} \ x$

                                                                                                                                                    Now,

                                                                                                                                                    Total amount $=$ Jon's money $+$ Miguel's money

                                                                                                                                                    $ \begin{aligned} x + x + 30 \% \ \text {of} \ x &= \pounds 46 \\ 2x + \dfrac {30} {100} \times x &= 46 \\ 2x + \dfrac {30x} {100} &= 46 \\ \dfrac {2x \times 100} {100} + \dfrac {30x} {100} &= 46 \\ \dfrac {200x + 30x} {100} &= 46 \\ 230x &= 46 \times 100 \\ x &= \dfrac {23 \times 2 \times 100} {23 \times 10} \\ &= \dfrac {\cancel {23} \times 2 \times 10 \cancel{0}} {\cancel {23} \times 1 \cancel{0}} \\ &= 2 \times 10 \\ &= \pounds 20 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                    Miguel has $\pounds 20$.

                                                                                                                                                    Jon has $46 - 20 = \pounds 26$

                                                                                                                                                    $\pounds 26$

                                                                                                                                                    dulwich-college--11-plus--maths--9999--specimen-paper-f.toml

                                                                                                                                                    rag_nm_pr

                                                                                                                                                  • 16D11FD8-0B06-4EA3-9482-8E3AAC14E2A8

                                                                                                                                                    • tmoney
                                                                                                                                                    • tfraction
                                                                                                                                                    • tpercentage

                                                                                                                                                    %empty%

                                                                                                                                                    %empty%

                                                                                                                                                    %empty%

                                                                                                                                                      • One third of $\pounds 120$.

                                                                                                                                                        $ \begin{aligned} &= \dfrac {1} {3} \text { of } \pounds 120 \\ &= \dfrac {1} {3} \times 120 \\ &= \dfrac {1 \times 40 \times 3} {3} \\ &= \dfrac {1 \times 40 \times \cancel {3}} {\cancel {3}} \\ &= \pounds 40 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                        $\pounds 40$

                                                                                                                                                        • $40\%$ of $\pounds 728$.

                                                                                                                                                          $ \begin{aligned} &= 40 \% \text { of } \pounds 728 \\ &= \dfrac {40} {100} \times 728 \\ &= \dfrac {4 \times 10 \times 728} {10 \times 10} \\ &= \dfrac {4 \times \cancel {10} \times 728} {10 \times \cancel {10}} \\ &= \dfrac {4 \times 728} {10} \\ &= \dfrac {2912} {10} \\ &= \pounds 291.2 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                          $\pounds 291.2$
