                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • tmoney

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              To encourage her to tidy her bedroom, Cathy is given $1 \text{p}$ on the first day, $2 \text{p}$ on the second day, $4 \text{p}$ on the third day and so on, doubling the amount each day. How much has she been given after $8$ days?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              TODOWORKING

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              rag_up_notstarted

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • F4D77903-BECE-4A44-88EA-1781F5A261B0

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • tmoney
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • tnumber

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Gavin buys four bottles of cola at $\pounds 1.09$ each and $8$ chocolate bars at $62 \text{p}$. How much change should he receive from a ten-pound note?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Price of Cola $= \pounds 1.09$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Price of $8$ Chocolate bars $= 62 \text{p}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              $ \begin{aligned} \text {Change received} &= 10 - (\text{Cost of cola} + \text{Cost of chocolate bars}) \\ &= 10 - (4 \times 1.09 + 62) \\ &= 10 - (4.36 + 62) \\ &= 10 - (4.36 + \dfrac {62} {100}) \\ &= 10 - (4.36 + 0.62) \\ &= 10 - 4.98 \\ &= \pounds 5.02 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              $\pounds 5.02$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              john-lyon-school--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-1.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              rag_ad_pr

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • 00C311D7-5CAB-401B-AE03-78A75AFA3E88

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • 700BB296-C63A-4D7F-A9BE-F09E3785CDC3

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • tmoney

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  A balloon pump and three packs of balloons cost $\pounds 9$ altogether.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  A balloon pump and four packs of balloons cost $\pounds 11$ altogether.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  %empty%

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  %empty%

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • How much does a pack of balloons cost?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $ \begin{aligned} \text {Cost of a pack of balloons} &= \text {Cost of a balloon pump and four packs of balloons} - \text {Cost of a balloon pump and three packs of balloons} \\ &= 11 - 9 \\ &= \pounds 2 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $\pounds 2$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • How much does a balloon pump and eight packs of balloons cost?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        $ \begin{aligned} \text {Cost of a balloon pump and eight packs of balloons} &= \text {Cost of a balloon pump} + 8 \times \text {Cost of a pack of balloons} \\ &= 3 + 8 \times 2 \\ &= 3 + 16 \\ &= \pounds 19 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        $\pounds 19$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      kent-college-canterbury--11-plus--maths--2020--sample-paper-1.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      rag_ad_pr

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • 3396FC7D-CAC5-48DF-9EEA-02DC624906F5

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • tmoney
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • tpercentage

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      %empty%

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      %empty%

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      %empty%

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Work out $50 \%$ of $58 \ \text{m}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          $ \begin{aligned} &= 50 \% \ \text {of} \ 58 \ \text{m} \\ &= \dfrac {50} {100} \times 58 \\ &= \dfrac {50 \times 58} {100} \\ &= \dfrac {50 \times 2 \times 29} {50 \times 2} \\ &= \dfrac {\cancel {50} \times \cancel {2} \times 29} {\cancel {50} \times \cancel {2}} \\ &= 29 \ \text{m} \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          $29 \ \text{m}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Work out $75 \%$ of $\pounds 24$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            $ \begin{aligned} &= 75 \% \ \text {of} \ \pounds 24 \\ &= \dfrac {75} {100} \times 24 \\ &= \dfrac {75 \times 24} {100} \\ &= \dfrac {25 \times 3 \times 4 \times 6} {25 \times 4} \\ &= \dfrac {\cancel {25} \times 3 \times \cancel {4} \times 6} {\cancel {25} \times \cancel {4}} \\ &= 3 \times 6 \\ &= \pounds 18 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            $\pounds 18$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Work out $10 \%$ of $130$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              $ \begin{aligned} &= 10 \% \ \text {of} \ 130 \\ &= \dfrac {10} {100} \times 130 \\ &= \dfrac {10 \times 130} {100} \\ &= \dfrac {1 \cancel {0} \times 13 \cancel {0}} {1 \cancel {0} \cancel {0}} \\ &= 13 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              $13$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            kent-college-canterbury--11-plus--maths--2020--sample-paper-1.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            rag_ad_pr

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Divide $9380$ by $35$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $ \begin{aligned} &= 9380 \div 35 \\ &= \dfrac {9380} {35} \\ &= \dfrac {\cancel{9380}} {\cancel{35}} \\ &= 268 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    %empty%

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    %empty%

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • $\dfrac{3}{8}$ of $11.2 \ \text{m}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        $ \begin {aligned} &= \dfrac {3} {8} \times {11.2 \ \text {m}} \\ &= \dfrac {3 \times 11.2} {8} \\ &= \dfrac {33.6} {8} \\ &= \dfrac {\cancel {33.6}} {\cancel {8}} \\ &= 4.2 \ \text {m} \end {aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        $4.2 \ \text {m}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • $0.3 \times 2 \ \text{kg}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          $ \begin {aligned} &= 0.3 \times {2 \ \text {kg}} \\ &= 0.6 \ \text {kg} \end {aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          $0.6 \text {kg}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • $28\%$ of $\pounds 50$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            $ \begin {aligned} &= \dfrac {28} {100} \times {50} \\ &= \dfrac {28 \times 50} {100} \\ &= \dfrac {1400} {100} \\ &= \dfrac { 14 \times 100 } {100} \\ &= \dfrac {14 \times \cancel {100}} {\cancel {100}} \\ &= 14 \ \text {pounds} \end {aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            $14 \ \text {pounds}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • $60\%$ of $\pounds 250$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              $ \begin {aligned} &= \dfrac {60} {100} \times {250} \\ &= \dfrac {60 \times 250} {100} \\ &= \dfrac {15000} {100} \\ &= \dfrac {150 \times \cancel {100}} {\cancel{100}} \\ &= 150 \ \text {pounds} \end {aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              $150 \ \text {pounds}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • $\dfrac{3}{8}$ of $\pounds 8.22$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                $ \begin {aligned} &= \dfrac {3} {8} \times {8.22} \\ &= \dfrac {3 \times 8.22} {8} \\ &= \dfrac {24.66} {8} \\ &= \dfrac {\cancel {24.66}} {\cancel {8}} \\ &= 3.0825 \ \text {pounds} \end {aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                $3.0825 \ \text {pounds}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              I buy $3$ chocolate bars for $65\ \text{pence}$ each and $5$ bags of crisps for $55 \ \text{p}$ each. How much change do I get from a $\pounds5$ note?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              A: $30\text{p}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              B: $35\text{p}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              C: $40\text{p}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              D: $45\text{p}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              E: $50\text{p}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              $ \begin {aligned} \text {Cost of three choclate bars} &= 1.95 \text{ pounds} \\ \text {Cost of five bags of crisps} &= 2.75 \text { pounds} \\ \text {Total savings} &= 5.00 {}- 1.95 {}- 2.75 \\ \text {Total savings} &= 0.3 \end {aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              TODOWORKING

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              0.3 pounds

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Work out $80\%$ of $\pounds535$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              A: $\pounds107$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              B: $\pounds372$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              C: $\pounds400$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              D: $\pounds418$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              E: $\pounds428$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              $ \begin {aligned} &= \dfrac {80} {100} \times 535 \\ &= \dfrac {80 \times 535} {100} \\ &= \dfrac {42,800} {100} \\ &= 428 \end {aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              I buy 4 Mega Bars at $65\ \text{pence}$ each and 3 Star Bars at $83\ \text{pence}$ each. How much change do I get from $\pounds10$?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              A: $\pounds4.91$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              B: $\pounds5.09$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              C: $\pounds5.91$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              D: $\pounds5.19$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              E: $\pounds4.81$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              $ \begin{aligned} \text {Change received} &= \pounds 10 - (65 \ \text {pence} \times 4 + 83\ \text{pence} \times 3) \\ &= \pounds 10 - (260 \ \text {pence} + 249 \ \text {pence}) \\ &= \pounds 10 - 509 \ \text {pence} \\ &= \pounds 10 - \pounds 5.09 \\ &= \pounds 4.91 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              $\pounds 4.91$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              latymer-upper-school--11-plus--maths--2020--sample-paper-1.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              I buy $7$ bags of Cheezos at $55\ \text{pence}$ each and $4$ bags of Nuttees at $63\ \text{pence}$ each. How much change do I get from $\pounds{10}$?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              A: $\pounds{3.73}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              B: $\pounds{3.63}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              C: $\pounds{4.73}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              D: $\pounds{4.63}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              E: $\pounds{6.37}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              $ \begin{aligned} \text {Change received} &= \pounds 10 - (7 \times 55 \text {p} + 4 \times 63 \text {p}) \\ &= \pounds 10 - (385 \text {p} + 252 \text {p}) \\ &= \pounds 10 - 637 \text {p} \\ &= \pounds 10 - \pounds 6.37 \\ &= \pounds 3.63 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              $\pounds 3.63$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Leyla buys a bracelet costing $\pounds6.49$. If she pays with a $\pounds10$ note what change should she receive?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        $ \begin{aligned} \text {Change received} &= \pounds 10 - \pounds 6.49 \\ &= \pounds 3.51 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        $\pounds 3.51$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        leicester-high-school-for-girls--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-1.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • FC723669-28F5-4DD7-8D03-9D1BA3DA811D

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • tmoney
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • tnumber

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Exercise books come in packs of $25$. The school needs $480$ exercise books.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        \begin{aligned}

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Curtain material costs $\pounds4.25 \ \text{per}\ \text{metre}$.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            %empty%

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            %empty%

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • How much will it cost to buy $10\ \text{metres}$?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} \text {Cost of 10 metres} &= 4.25 \times 10 \\ &= \pounds 42.5 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                $\pounds 42.5$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Mrs Brown buys a length of this material and pays $\pounds17$.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  How many metres does she buy?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  $ \begin{aligned} \text {She buys} &= \dfrac {17} {4.25} \\ &= \dfrac {4 \times \cancel {4.25}} {\cancel {4.25}} \\ &= 4 \text{metres} \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  $4 \text{metres}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                leicester-high-school-for-girls--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-2.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                rag_ad_red

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • 02AE8DFB-4F87-46DA-95B0-D6783C21CA17

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • tmoney

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                A return train ticket for an adult travelling from Leicester to Cambridge costs $\pounds29.40$.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                %empty%

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                %empty%

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Find the cost of $3$ adult return tickets.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    $ \begin{aligned} \text {Cost of 3 adult tickets} &= 29.40 \times 3 \\ &= \pounds 88.2 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    $\pounds 88.2$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • The price of a childrens ticket is half that of an adult ticket. What is the cost of a return ticket for a child travelling from Leicester to Cambridge?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $ \begin{aligned} \text {Cost of a child ticket} &= \dfrac {29.40} {2} \\ &= \dfrac {14.7 \times 2} {2} \\ &= \dfrac {14.7 \times \cancel {2}} {\cancel {2}} \\ &= \pounds 14.7 \\ \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      So cost of a return ticket for a child travelling from Leicester to Cambridge is $\pounds 14.7$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $\pounds 14.7$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    leicester-high-school-for-girls--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-2.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    rag_ad_pr

How many boxes of $24$ pencils should the school buy, and how many spare pencils will this leave?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        leicester-high-school-for-girls--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-3.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        rag_up_notstarted

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • 1E6D1523-E176-4AD8-9E79-64FF9FF7EBEE

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • tmoney
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • tfraction

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Calculate

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        %empty%

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        %empty%

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • one third of $\pounds25.74$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            $ \begin{aligned} &= \dfrac {1} {3} \ \text {of} \ \pounds 25.74 \\ &= \dfrac {1} {3} \times 25.74 \\ &= \dfrac {25.74} {3} \\ &= \dfrac {3 \times 8.58} {3} \\ &= \dfrac {\cancel {3} \times 8.58} {\cancel {3}} \\ &= \pounds 8.58 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            $\pounds 8.58$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • $\dfrac{3} {4}$ of $180\degree$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              $ \begin{aligned} &= \dfrac {3} {4} \ \text {of} \ 180 \degree \\ &= \dfrac {3} {4} \times 180 \degree \\ &= \dfrac {3 \times 180} {4} \\ &= \dfrac {3 \times 45 \times 4} {4} \\ &= \dfrac {3 \times 45 \times \cancel {4}} { \cancel {4}} \\ &= 135 \degree \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              $135 \degree$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            leicester-high-school-for-girls--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-3.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            rag_ad_g1

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • 7ED0E8A6-8797-4138-A006-85F2D567D9C5

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • tmoney

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Mrs Cook‚Äôs supermarket basket contains:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            $1$ loaf of bread costing $68\text{p}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            $1$ packet of cheese costing $\pounds3.29$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            $5$ packets of crisps at $22\text{p}$ each

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            $2$ tins of soup at $39\text{p}$ each.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Calculate how much change she will receive if she pays with a $\pounds20$ note.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            $ \begin{aligned} \text {Change she will receive} &= \pounds \ 20 - (68 \ \text{p} + \pounds \ 3.29 + 5 \times 22 \ \text{p} + 2 \times 39 \ \text{p}) \\ &= \pounds \ 20 - (\pounds \ 0.68 + \pounds \ 3.29 + \pounds \ 0.22 + \pounds \ 0.39) \\ &= 20 - 4.58 \\ &= \pounds \ 15.42 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            $\pounds \ 15.42$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            leicester-high-school-for-girls--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-3.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            rag_ad_pr

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • A2F4CE02-CC08-4549-9659-71797B3FFB94

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • tmoney
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • tpercentageadvance

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    If $25\%$ of the cost of building a boat is for materials. Calculate the cost of the materials in a boat costing $\pounds6000$ to build.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    $ \begin{aligned} \text {Cost of the materials costing} \pounds 6000 \text{to build} &= 25 \% \ \text {of} \ \pounds 6000 \\ &= \dfrac {25} {100} \times 6000 \\ &= \dfrac {25 \times 6000} {100} \\ &= \dfrac {25 \times 60 \cancel {0} \cancel {0}} {1 \cancel {0} \cancel {0}} \\ &= 60 \times 25 \\ &= \pounds 1500 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    $\pounds 1500$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    leicester-high-school-for-girls--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-3.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    rag_ad_pr

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • EA606B10-54A7-4F41-A53A-9815B0AF5B43

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • tpercentage
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • tmoney

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    A cup of coffee costs $\pounds2.50$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    The diagram shows how much money different people get when you buy a cup of coffee.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    TODOWORKING

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    TODOWORKING

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    TODOANSWER

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Complete the table to show what percentage of the cost of a cup of coffee goes to retailers, growers and others.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Show your working.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Retailers$\%$
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Growers$\%$
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Others$\%$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      leicester-high-school-for-girls--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-4.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      rag_up_notstarted

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • FB9C0752-B2BA-49B8-96AA-048619C2539C

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • tmoney
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • tfraction

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Find:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      %empty%

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      %empty%

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • $30\%$ of $\pounds 70$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          $ \begin{aligned} &= 30 \% \text { of } \pounds 70 \\ &= \dfrac {30} {100} \times 70 \\ &= \dfrac {30 \times 70} {100} \\ &= \dfrac {3 \cancel {0} \times 7 \cancel {0}} {1 \cancel {0} \cancel {0}} \\ &= 3 \times 7 \\ &= \pounds 21 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          $\pounds 21$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • a fifth of $\pounds 70$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            $ \begin{aligned} &= \text {a fifth of } \pounds 70 \\ &= \dfrac {1} {5} \times 70 \\ &= \dfrac {70} {5} \\ &= \dfrac {5 \times 14} {5} \\ &= \dfrac {\cancel {5} \times 14} {\cancel {5}} \\ &= \pounds 14 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            $\pounds 14$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • $80\%$ of a half of $\pounds 70$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              $ \begin{aligned} &= 80 \% \text { of a half of } \pounds 70 \\ &= \dfrac {80} {100} \times \dfrac {1} {2} \times 70 \\ &= \dfrac {80 \times 70} {100 \times 2} \\ &= \dfrac {40 \times 2 \times 70} {100 \times 2} \\ &= \dfrac {4 \cancel {0} \times \cancel {2} \times 7 \cancel {0}} {1 \cancel {0} \cancel {0} \times \cancel {2}} \\ &= 4 \times 7 \\ &= \pounds 28 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              $\pounds 28$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            magdalen-college-school--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-1.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            rag_ad_g2

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • C7E5C1F7-F102-4A2B-A59C-05452CBF4FE0

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • tmoney
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • talgebra

He chose to spend it on pens and pencils
