                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  rag_up_notstarted

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • 51C00E11-4522-456E-9573-8B2298390591

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • tmoney

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Angela works for a computer firm. She is paid $\pounds 10000$, plus $\pounds 100$ for each computer she sells. How much will she earn if she sells:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  %empty%

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  %empty%

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • $15$ computers

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $ \begin{aligned} &= 15 \times 100 \\ &= \pounds 1500 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $\pounds 1500$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • How many computers does she sell if she earns $\pounds 12600$?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        $ \begin{aligned} &= \dfrac {12600} {100} \\ &= \dfrac {126 \cancel {0} \cancel {0}} {1 \cancel {0} \cancel {0}} \\ &= 126 \text { computers} \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        $126 \text { computers}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      merchant-taylors-school--11-plus--maths--2008--practice-paper-1.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      rag_ad_pr

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • 180F757E-01D0-440D-A6AD-2B7A83661632

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • tpercentage
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • tmoney
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • tunitprompt

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Find:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      %empty%

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      %empty%

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • $20\%$ of $\pounds 840$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          $ \begin{aligned} &= 20 \% \ \text {of} \ \pounds 840 \\ &= \dfrac {20} {100} \times 840 \\ &= \dfrac {20 \times 840} {100} \\ &= \dfrac {2 \cancel {0} \times 84 \cancel {0}} {1 \cancel {0} \cancel {0}} \\ &= 2 \times 84 \\ &= \pounds 168 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          $168$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • $12 \dfrac{1}{2}\%$ of $6.80 \ \text{metres}$, giving your answer in centimetres.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            $ \begin{aligned} &= 12 \ \dfrac {1} {2} \% \ \text {of} \ 6.80 \ \text{meters} \\ &= \dfrac {25} {2 \times 100} \times 6.8 \times 100 \ \text{centimeters} \\ &= \dfrac {25} {2 \times 100} \times \dfrac {68} {10} \times 100 \\ &= \dfrac {25 \times 68 \times 100} {2 \times 100 \times 10} \\ &= \dfrac {5 \times 5 \times 2 \times 2 \times 17 \times 100} {2 \times 100 \times 5 \times 2} \\ &= \dfrac {\cancel {5} \times 5 \times \cancel {2} \times \cancel {2} \times 17 \times \cancel {100}} {\cancel {2} \times \cancel {100} \times \cancel {5} \times \cancel {2}} \\ &= 17 \times 5 \\ &= 85 \ \text{centimeters} \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            $85 \ \text{centimeters}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          merchant-taylors-school--11-plus--maths--2008--practice-paper-1.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          rag_ad_g1

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • 4D36DDE1-18A4-4F91-A9F3-7CB993E6A6E3

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • tmoney
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • tunitprompt
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • tprofit

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Mark has a market stall. He sells apples at $56 \text{p}$ for each kilogram.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Bianca buys $4 \ \text{kilograms}$ of apples. She pays for her apples with a $\pounds 5$ note.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          %empty%

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          %empty%

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • How much change should she get?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              $ \begin{aligned} \text {Change she should get} &= \pounds 5 - 4 \times 56 \text{p} \\ &= \pounds 5 - 224 \text{p} \\ &= \pounds 5 - \pounds 2.24 \\ &= \pounds 2.76 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              $\pounds 2.76$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Mark bought $25$ melons for his stall. He paid $\pounds 16$ for $25$each melons.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Work out the price Mark paid for each melon, in pence.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Since we know,

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                \pounds 1 = 100 \text { p}

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} &= \pounds 16 \times 100 \\ &= 1600 \text { p} \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                $1600 \text { p}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Five of the melons were bad. Mark sold the other $20$ for $120 \text{p}$ each.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Work out the total amount for which Mark sold the melons.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  $ \begin{aligned} &= 20 \times 120 \text { p} \\ &= 2400 \text { p} \\ &= \pounds 24 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  $\pounds 24$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Work out what profit Mark made in selling the melons, giving your answer as a fraction of the cost of buying the melons.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    $ \begin{aligned} \text {Profit} &= \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    TODOANSWER

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  $2$ packets of crisps and $2$ drinks costs $\pounds 1.50$. $2$ packets of crisps and $1$ drink costs $\pounds 1.10$. What would it cost me if I buy $3$ packets of crisps and $4$ drinks?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Three bicycles are priced at $\pounds 79, \pounds 80$ and $\pounds 84$. If the shopkeeper decided to sell them for the same total amount, but made the three prices equal, what would each cost?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  $81$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  $81$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  merchant-taylors-school--11-plus--maths--2009--practice-paper-2.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  rag_ad_pr

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • 370E6891-00C4-4400-9412-56FFA4BE4110

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • tmoney

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  A car hire firm charges $\pounds 35$ per day plus $34 \text{p}$ per km travelled. A man hired a car for $4$ days and travelled $300 \ \text{km}$. How much did he pay?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  $ \begin{aligned} \text {Man pays for 4 days and 300km} &= 4 \times \pounds 35 + 300 \times 34 \text {p} \\ &= \pounds 140 + 10200 \text {p} \\ &= \pounds 140 + \pounds 102 \\ &= \pounds 242 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  $\pounds 242$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  merchant-taylors-school--11-plus--maths--2009--practice-paper-2.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  rag_ad_pr

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Jeff goes to the cinema. He buys a ticket for $\pounds 5.75$, popcorn for $\pounds 1.50$ and a drink for $76 \text{p}$. His return train fare is $\pounds 3.80$. If he leaves home with a $\pounds 20$ note how much change does he return with?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $ \begin{aligned} \text {Change he will receive} &= \pounds 20 - (\pounds 5.75 + \pounds 1.50 + 76 \text {p} + \pounds 3.80) \\ &= \pounds 20 - (\pounds 5.75 + \pounds 1.50 + \pounds 0.76 + \pounds 3.80) \\ &= 20 - 11.81 \\ &= \pounds 8.19 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $\pounds 8.19$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      merchant-taylors-school--11-plus--maths--9999--practice-paper-3.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      rag_ad_pr

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • 7FE7F568-7B71-4112-B005-8AAA4EE29378

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • tmoney

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $\pounds 50000$ in $\pounds 50$ notes weighs about $1.3 \ \text{Kg}$. How much, in grams, does one $\pounds 50$ note weigh?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $ \begin{aligned} \pounds 50000 \text { in } \pounds 50 \text { notes weighs} &= 1.3 \text {kg} \\ \text {Weight of one} \pounds 50 &= \dfrac {1.3 \text {kg}} {50000} \\ &= \dfrac {1300 \text { g}} {50000} \\ &= \dfrac {13 \cancel {0} \cancel {0}} {500 \cancel {0} \cancel {0}} \\ &= \dfrac {13} {500} \\ &= 0.026 \ \text {g} \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $0.026 \ \text {g}$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      merchant-taylors-school--11-plus--maths--9999--practice-paper-3.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      rag_ad_pr

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • D8CD86EC-CEA6-473B-8C9B-8CCE13207DB6

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • tmoney
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • tcoin

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Fazal has $\pounds 2.60$ and Gareth has $\pounds 5.30$. Gareth gives Fazal some $5 \text{p}$ coins. Each boy now has the same amount of money. How many $5 \text{p}$ coins did Gareth give Fazal?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Five bags of apples cost $\pounds 3.25$.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      How much would $\text{seven}$ bags of apples cost?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $ \begin{aligned} \text {Cost of 5 bags} &= \pounds 3.25\\ \text {Cost of 1 bag} &= \dfrac {3.25} {5} \\ &= \dfrac {0.65 \times 5} {5} \\ &= \dfrac {0.65 \times \cancel {5}} {\cancel {5}} \\ &= \pounds 0.65 \\ \text {Cost of 7 bags} &= 0.65 \times 7 \\ &= \pounds 4.55 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $\pounds 4.55$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      north-london-collegiate-school--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-1.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      rag_ad_red

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • BB2373FF-1D5B-413C-8160-D9BBA4F4E551

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • tmoney

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Mrs Jones prints books.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Jon pays $\bold{\pounds 4.35}$ for his book, including the cover.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      How many pages are in his book?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Let the number of pages $=a$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      As per the question,

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $ \begin{aligned} 3 \times a + 75 &= 435 \\ 3 \times a &= 435 - 75 \\ 3 \times a &= 360 \\ a &= \dfrac {360} {3} \\ a &= \dfrac {120 \times 3} {3} \\ a &= \dfrac {120 \times \cancel {3}} {\cancel {3}} \\ a &= 120 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $120$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      north-london-collegiate-school--11-plus--maths--9999--sample-paper-1.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      rag_ad_pr

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • D7B8557B-C51F-4733-8A8F-653E8E463B35

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • tmoney

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Five friends shared the cost of a mansion (priced at $3$ million pounds) equally. How much did each of them pay ?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $ \begin{aligned} \text{Let the amount given be each friend} &= x \\ 5x &= 3000000 \\ x &= \dfrac {3000000} {5} \\ &= \dfrac {600000 \times \cancel{5} {\cancel{5}}} \\ x &= 600000 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $600000$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      oundle-school--11-plus--maths--2008--sample-paper-1.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      rag_ks_g1

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • tcoin

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Susan‚Äôs bus fare is exactly $44 \text{p}$. If the driver can give her change, what is the smallest number of coins that can change hands when Susan pays to get on the bus ? (Explain clearly)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      \text{change = 56 p , So 105 and 55 and 1*1}

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $56 p , So 105 and 55 and 1*1$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      oundle-school--11-plus--maths--2008--sample-paper-1.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      rag_ks_pr

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • 4471FF90-E8D7-4ED1-8FDA-C346A528851A

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • tmoney
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • talgebra

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Two workers are paid a total of $\pounds 506$ by their employer. If one is paid $20\%$ more than the other, how much do they each earn?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $ \begin{aligned} \text{Let the wage of first labourer = x} \\ \text{Therefore wage of second labourer} &= x + \dfrac{20}{100} \times x \\ &= \dfrac{100 \times x + 20x}{100} \\ &= \dfrac{120x}{100} \\ \text{Total wages} &= 506 \\ x + \dfrac{120x}{100} &= 506 \\ \dfrac{100x + 120x}{100} &= 506 \\ \dfrac{220x}{100} &= 506 \\ x &= \dfrac{506 \times 100} {220} \\ x &= 23 \\ \text{Wage of other worker} &= 506 - 23 \\ &= 483 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $23,483$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      oundle-school--11-plus--maths--2016--sample-paper-2.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      rag_ks_g1

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • 3B2F88FB-098F-446B-A5EA-C78BF6D5E9A0

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • tdate
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • tmoney

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      In March $1998$ a book called ‚ÄúThe Shadow of the East‚Äù was returned to a library in Sussex. It had been borrowed on January $3 \text{rd} 1924$! The library charges a fine of $60 \text{p}$ per week for overdue books. Approximately how big a fine should the person who returned the book have paid?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • tpercentageadvance

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  An iPad used to cost $\pounds 330$. Since Brexit the price has increased by $22\%$.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  How much does it cost now?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  $ \begin{aligned} &= 22 \% \times 330 \\ &= \dfrac{22}{100} \times 330 \\ &= \dfrac{22 \times 330}{100} \\ &= \dfrac{7260} {100} \\ &= \dfrac{726 \cancel {0}} {10 \cancel{0}} \\ &= 72.6 \\ &= 330 + 72.6 \\ &= 402.6 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  $402.6$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  oundle-school--11-plus--maths--2017--sample-paper-5.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  rag_ks_g1

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • 154CF3A5-8DE7-4C0B-BB62-B260198A6014

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • tnumber
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • tmoney
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • tstatistics
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • tpercentageadvance

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • A car is $3.28 \ \text{metres}$ long. A trailer is $1.86 \ \text{metres}$ long.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      What is the combined length?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $ \begin{array}{cccc} & 3 \ . & 2 & 8 \ {}+ & 1 \ . & 8 & 6 \ \hline & 5 \ . & 1 & 4 \ \end{array} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      $5.14$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • A pallet of bricks contains $648$ bricks.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Calculate he number of bricks in $37$ pallets.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        $ \begin{array}{ccccccccc} & & & 6 & 4 & 8 \ {} & &\times & & 3 & 7 \ \hline & & 4 & 5 & 3 & 6 \ & 1 & 9 & 4 & 4 & 0 \ \hline & 2 & 3 & 9 & 7 & 6 \end{array} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        $23976$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • One kilogram of carrots cost $\pounds 1.79$.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          What does $0.37 \ \text{kilograms}$ of carrots cost (to the nearest pence)?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          $ \begin{array}{cccc} & 1 \ . & 7 & 9 \ \times & 0 \ . & 3 & 7 \ \hline & 0 \ . & 6 & 6 & 2 & 3 \ \end{array} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          $0.6623$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • There are $0.907 \ \text{metres}$ in $1$ yard. How many metres are there in $0.026 \ \text{yards}$?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            $ \begin{array}{cccc} & 0 \ . & 9 & 0 & 7 \ \times & 0 \ . & 0 & 2 & 6 \ \hline & 0 \ . & 0 & 2 & 3 & 5 & 8 & 2 \ \end{array} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            $0.023582$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • The total length of seven cars is $22.19 \ \text{metres}$. What is the average length of these cars?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Work out $11 + 39 \div 13 - 5 \times 3$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} &= 11 + 39 \div 13 - 5 \times 3 \\ &= 11 + 3 - 15 \\ &= -1 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                $-1$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • $67\%$ of all pencils manufactured are never used up.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  In a bulk pack of $3490$ pencils, how many will not be used up?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  +$ \begin{aligned} &= 67 \% \times 3490 \\ &= \dfrac{67}{100} \times 3490 \\ &= \dfrac{67 \times 3490}{100} \\ &= \dfrac{233830} {100} \\ &= \dfrac{23383 \cancel {0}} {10 \cancel{0}} \\ &= 2338.3 \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  $2338.3$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                oundle-school--11-plus--maths--2017--sample-paper-7.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                rag_ks_amber

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • 3AFA86B0-9BFB-41F8-900A-072D2C1A833D

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • tmoney
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • tpercentageadvance

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                A bicycle at Store $P$ costs $$200$. The regular price of the same bicycle at Store $Q$ is $15\%$ more than it is at Store P. The bicycle is on sale at Store Q for $10\%$ off of the regular price.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                What is the sale price of the bicycle at Store $Q$?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                $ \begin{aligned} \text{Cost of bicycle at store P} &= 200 \\ \text{Price at store} &= 15 \% 200 + 200 \\ &= \dfrac{15 \times 200}{100} + 200 \\ &= 30 + 200 \\ &= 230 \\ \text{Price at store Q} &= 230 - 10 \% 200\\ &= 230 - 20 \\ &= 210

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                \end{aligned} $

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                $210$

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                oundle-school--11-plus--maths--2017--sample-paper-7.toml

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                rag_ks_g1

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • C3168C71-1453-467B-B9E0-F3062E77C342

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • tnumber

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    $ \begin{array}{cccc} & 2 \ . & 4 & 6 \ {}+ & 1 \ . & 2 & 9 \ \hline & 4 \ . & 7 & 5 \ \end{array} $
